title: Unit 8 Checkpoint: Three-Dimensional Geometry
description: Summative checkpoint assessing mastery of volume and surface area formulas for prisms, cylinders, pyramids, cones, and spheres, including the 1/3 relationship and real-world applications.

remediationResources.reteachFocus: V=Bh, identify base shape first, rectangular V=lwh, cylinder V=πr²h
V=(1/3)Bh for pyramids/cones (1/3 of corresponding prism), sphere V=(4/3)πr³
SA=2B+Ph for prisms, SA=2πr²+2πrh for cylinders, unfold to see net
Slant height vs vertical height, l²=r²+h² for cones, SA=πr²+πrl, sphere SA=4πr²

assessmentProblems.question: A cylinder has radius 6 and height 11. Find the volume in terms of π.
A rectangular prism has dimensions 7 × 9 × 12. Find the volume and surface area.
A cone has radius 9 and height 12. Find the volume in terms of π.
A square pyramid has a base edge of 8 and a height of 9. Find the volume.
A sphere has radius 6. Find the volume and surface area in terms of π.
A cylinder has radius 5 and height 14. Find the surface area in terms of π.
A cone has radius 8 and height 15. Find the slant height and the total surface area in terms of π.
A sphere has a volume of 500π/3 cm³. Find the radius.
A cone and a cylinder have the same radius (4) and height (9). Find both volumes and verify the 1:3 relationship.

ANALYSIS: A cylindrical water tank has diameter 10 feet and height 8 feet. (a) Find the volume in cubic feet. (b) One cubic foot holds 7.48 gallons. How many gallons does the tank hold? Round to nearest gallon.

spiralReview.question: SPIRAL (Similarity): △ABC ~ △DEF with scale factor 2:3. If AB = 14, find DE.
SPIRAL (Inscribed Angles): An inscribed angle intercepts an arc of 134°. Find the inscribed angle.
